headline: Braised Squid With Tomato, Harissa, and Olives Recipe
description: Most recipes for squid focus on quick-cooking techniques, like sautéing and frying, but braised squid is arguably one of the most delicious ways to prepare it. This recipe features braised squid in a spicy tomato sauce with olives and lemon zest.
name: Braised Squid With Tomato, Harissa, and Olives Recipe
recipeIngredient: 1 small yellow onion (6 ounces; 170g), quartered and thinly sliced
2 pounds (1kg) cleaned squid bodies and tentacles, bodies sliced into 1/2-inch rings and large tentacles halved
1 (28-ounce; 800g) can whole peeled tomatoes, preferably San Marzano, crushed by hand
1/2 tablespoon (8ml) fresh harissa paste or store-bought
2 teaspoons (10ml) finely grated zest from 1/2 lemon
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
Small handful minced fresh parsley leaves

recipeInstructions.text: In a large saucepan, heat olive oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onion and garlic and cook, stirring, until softened but not browned, about 4 minutes.

Add wine and squid, bring to a simmer, and cook, stirring occasionally, until alcohol smell has mostly cooked off, about 3 minutes. Stir in tomatoes, thyme sprigs, and olives and return to a simmer. Lower heat to maintain a gentle simmer and cook, stirring occasionally, until squid is tender, about 30 minutes. Discard thyme.
Stir in harissa and lemon zest, season with salt and pepper, sprinkle parsley on top, and serve.

review.reviewBody: Made this exactly as written, except I also squeezed fresh lemon juice on before serving. It added a nice bright acidity! Served with pearled couscous. Delicious! 10/10 would make again! I’m not a big fan of very spicy food but found the 1/2 tbsp of Harrisa to add just enough heat and depth of flavor. My husband is more of a hothead and thinks we could add more, but when he did that with his serving I tasted it and thought it blew out the other subtle, wonderful flavors.
Is that 2 pounds of squid before or after cleaning?

Made this very tasty dish tonight and was seriously not dissapointed! 
Find squid to be a cheap sea food (in Ireland anyhow) though its not always available. 
Usually pan fry squid but never tried slow cooking it. 
 Used green olives (as i hadnt any black) threw in a few capers and used a sliced preserved lemon instead of lemon zest. Truley delicious, will definately make this again and again!

I made this last night and added 1TB of harissa and didn't cut the tentacles. It was excellent! Very tender and juicy calamari
 There is enough leftover that I will put it over spaghetti tonight. I will definitely make this again!

I normally check out grocery markets whenever I travel. From western sea coast to the eastern sea coast of US. I feel very fortunate that I have fair access to seafood here in the Bay Area. Walking distance to Japanese and Asian markets. But even with this, it's not great like it is in Japan. Some of the markets in the mid America have almost nothing except tilapia, maybe farmed icky looking shrimp, etc. No wonder you get less traffic when writing about seafood or fish here. Many do not even know or even tasted some of the seafood you write about. It is a shame though but continue writing about them. Thanks! This squid recipe looks good and I must try this one too.

item.name: Braised Squid With Tomato, Harissa, and Olives Recipe
